snippet.title:
Chocogasms & dogs Chocolate contains substances known as methylxanthines (specifically caffeine and theobromine), which dogs are far more sensitive to than people. Different types of chocolate contain varying amounts of methylxanthines. In general, though, the darker and more bitter the chocolate the greater the danger.
For instance, 8 ounces (a ½ pound) of milk chocolate may sicken a 50-pound dog, whereas a dog of the same size can be poisoned by as little as 1 ounce of Baker's chocolate!
Why Isn't Chocolate Toxic to Humans? Humans can break down and excrete methylxanthines such as theobromine much more efficiently than dogs.
Know more about this: http://www.petmd.com/dog/chocolate-toxicity Photo credit: see the watermark on the pic ﻿

Danielle Castaldo http://ow.ly/tzq8v
Cherries Dipped in White Chocolate (Photo by Cindy C.)
3 cups of cherries 1 cup white chocolate chips or baking chocolate 1 packet of silver sugar pearls
Line a baking tray that will fit in your fridge with baking paper.
Melt chocolate in the microwave or in a bowl over a barely simmering saucepan of water.
Dip the cherries into the melted chocolate a few times then place on the baking tray. While the chocolate is still wet, drop pinches of sugar pearls onto the chocolate.
Place the cherries in the fridge until the chocolate is set.

Chocolate Zucchini Cake. I had to shoot this photo fast as I was giving it away to a friend within an hour of making it! I kept it simple by placing the dark cake onto my cake stand. I proceeded to cover the cake with a doily and sift icing sugar on top (this way showing the cake against a stark white.) I like the little bit of excess sugar that landed on the cake stand. Natural light from the right, reflected with a white foam board. Shot from above with a tripod and kept simple.
http://www.thecookiewriter.com/2014/04/chocolate-zucchini-cake.html﻿
